location.physicalLocation: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

mods.abstract: This group of formally dressed African American men and women are posed on the steps of a frame building with brick foundation. The location is the same as a 1908-1909 image of LeMoyne Normal Institute in which Principal L.T. Larsen poses with students and teachers. In this image, the men wear suits and ties; the women high collared shirtwaist dresses or skirt and blouse combinations. Two students in the front row display a LeMoyne pennant.

titleInfo.title: Courtesy LeMoyne-Owen College Library Special Collections

mods.accessCondition: Copyright of the creator. Reproduced with permission. Reproduction permitted for non-profit educational and research purposes only. For publication inquiries or to obtain a high resolution image, contact LeMoyne-Owen College Library Special Collections.

relatedItem.abstract: Tennessee’s history between the end of the American Civil War (1865) and the end of World War II (1945) often gets ignored. Citizenship—what that has meant and how that has changed—is at the heart of this digital exploration into Tennessee history and culture “between the wars." The stories you can explore through the objects, songs, photographs, paintings, and documents of this website are often those of challenges and obstacles placed before those who pursued the rights and benefits of citizenship.

mods.note: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
